@graph.reasoning: This antitrust case concerns the acquisition of red alder sawlogs by the mills that process those logs in the Pacific Northwest.

@graph.@id: Brooke Group Ltd. v. Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp., 509 U. S. 209 (1993)
@graph.reasoning: We hold that the test we applied to claims of predatory pricing in Brooke Group Ltd. v. Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp. also applies to claims of predatory bidding.

@graph.@id: Confederated Tribes of Siletz Indians of Ore. v. Weyerhaeuser Co., 411 F. 3d 1030 (2005)
involvedParties: Confederated Tribes of Siletz Indians of Ore.
@graph.reasoning: The Court of Appeals reasoned that 'buy-side predatory bidding' and 'sell-side predatory pricing,' though similar, are materially different in that predatory bidding does not necessarily benefit consumers or stimulate competition in the way that predatory pricing does.
